thread.title: United Airlines cabin crew and air marshal forced to tie aggressive passenger to seat
thread.title_full: United Airlines cabin crew and air marshal forced to tie aggressive passenger to seat | Daily Mail Online

author: John Hutchinson for MailOnline
title: United Airlines cabin crew and air marshal forced to tie aggressive passenger to seat
text:
10 shares 2
View
comments
An aggressive passenger was tied up by cabin crew and the air marshal on a United Airlines flight from Israel to the U.S.
Despite the incident on board the Boeing 777-200, the pilot didn't take the decision to make an emergency landing.
Flight UAL85 had flown out of Ben Gurion International Airport in Tel Aviv at 12.37 yesterday, en-route to Newark Liberty in New Jersey.
Scroll down for video
The aggressive passenger was tied up on the United Airlines flight from Tel Aviv to New Jersey
But during the 11-hour flight a passenger became aggressive and had to be strapped to the seat with tie wraps.
Twitter user @News_Executive told MailOnline Travel that the passenger in question was a male, around 40 years old.
 The female solo backpacker who braved civil war to capture... Pictured: Horrific foot injuries suffered by pregnant woman... Are we there yet? 'Big Crazy Family Adventure' sees parents... Are these the world's BEST hotels? A Caribbean hideaway, an... When the plane landed in Newark, four police officers entered the cabin and removed the man from the aircraft.
The air marshal, also known as a sky marshal, is an undercover law enforcement or counter terrorist agent on board a commercial aircraft deployed to counter aircraft hijackings.
United Airlines told MailOnline Travel in a statement: 'United flight 85 from Tel Aviv to Newark arrived on schedule following a situation that occurred when a flight attendant attempted to help calm an agitated customer.
'The flight attendant was not injured. Though law enforcement officials met the aircraft as a precaution, customers and crew members exited and departed normally.'
After the plane landed, four police officers came on board and removed the aggressive male
